story:
“The Writers’ Studio made my love for writing grow stronger and confirmed that I should keep doing it.”

—Dayja

YOU can help shape a young writer’s future. The 7th annual Baltimore Young Writers' Summer Studio offers 6th - 12th grade students from low-income Baltimore City schools an immersive, transformative six-day retreat at Mar-Lu-Ridge Retreat Center in Jefferson, Maryland. The Summer Writers’ Studio is an extension of Writers in Baltimore School’s (WBS) ongoing in-school and after-school programs. Last year, your donations enabled 32 talented young writers to attend the Summer Studio Camp, a life changing experience.

The 2018 program will be held from August 5-10, and with your help, we will be able to serve 32 youth. For many campers, the Writers’ Studio Camp is their first experience outside of Baltimore City, and often their first experience away from home. Help us raise $12,000 by July 15 to subsidize the cost of the camp experience for these promising young writers. The Studio is completely free to all campers.

Who We Are

“WBS is more than a program or a camp. It is like home. I found myself in my writing. WBS is like a family, a forever family.”

— Bryonna

Founded in 2008, WBS empowers the voices of Baltimore City students through in-school, after-school, and summer programming that builds skills in literacy and communication while creating a community of support for young writers. Over the past 9 years, WBS has held OST writing groups at 8 schools. We have served 800+ Baltimore City Public Schools (BCPS) students through 51 in-school courses, 46 after-school writing clubs and 9 multi-day summer programs. We give underserved students a smaller, more participatory setting to hone reading and writing skills – replicating the advantages of their wealthier peers. Our summer studio program provides a rare opportunity for low-income Baltimore City youth to stay in a rural setting at a mountain retreat.

WBS students’ writing has appeared in the Poetry Foundation blog, The Washington Post, The Baltimore Sun, The Baltimore City Paper, and Baltimore Beat. For the past four summers, WBS students have received full scholarships to attend the Iowa Young Writers’ Studio and the Kenyon Review Young Writers Workshop.

What We Need

We need to raise $12,000 by July 15. So far, we've raised $18,000 from local foundations and individuals. Through our Indieogo campaign, we hope to raise the remaining $12,000 needed to make the Studio a reality.

Impact

 

“This camp opened new doors for me. Doors that I didn't even know could be opened.”

— Marie

 

“The Studio made me feel more excited when I write. I don’t feel the same at home.”

—Joanna

 

Your gift enables young writers to experience daily Studio workshops focus on topics such as story structure, sentence structure, grammar for writers, character development, point of view, science fiction, and revision. Outside of classroom time, students enjoy hikes, ghost story competitions, swimming, s’mores around a campfire, and a talent show. The Studio culminates in publication of an anthology of student work and an open mic back in Baltimore, to allow for family and community members to attend.

 

Gift Levels and Perks

$10 — Your gift of $10 or more will be acknowledged on the Writers in Baltimore Schools website and Facebook page.

$25 — For $25, receive a postcard with a writing prompt written by a young writer.

$50 — For $50, receive a copy of Baltimore by Hand, the 2017 - 2018 anthology of Writers in Baltimore Schools.

$75 — For $75, receive a WBS tote bag or t-shirt. Your choice!

$100 — For $100, receive a notebook featuring a student’s poem on the cover.

$250 — For $250, receive a WBS tote bag, t-shirt, and notebook!

$500 — For $500, receive a reading list put together by the young writers at the Studio.

$1,000 — For $1,000, receive a reading list and booklet of writing prompts created by the young writers at the Studio.

Or, you can always provide a gift of any amount of your choice! 100% of every donation is tax-deductible and goes towards helping low-income teens benefit from the Writers’ Studio experience.

story:
Story of My Book

My name is Madison Troutz, and I am the author of iExperience: The Future of Museums. I wrote this book because I believe there is a need for certain topics to be addressed within the industry such as inclusivity, the rise of technology, and the revitalization of the museum industry.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover that there is a need for a revitalization of the museum industry. In this book, I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for experiential engagement and immersive exhibitions in you. And then ultimately, I want you to see this book as a guide to start having conversations about how museums can better cater to you, the visitors. Moreover, I hope this book serves as a guide toward the future and the important steps that need to be taken.

In this book, you'll learn about how in order to look toward the future, first, we must look toward our past:

  • The Child Within - In this chapter, I go through how maybe the experiences we had in our childhood might be the key to revitalizing the museum industry.
  • Building Immersion - This chapter talks about how to build an immersive exhibition, what an immersive exhibition looks like, and how it can be incorporated into a museum setting.
  • The Redesign - This chapter goes in-depth, through what we need to do in order to revitalize the industry.
You will love this book if you love activism, technology, museums, or even a captivating read.
iExperience is a non-fiction book that speaks to museum-goers and museum professionals who are looking at the future of the industry, are curious, and open to the possibilities of what lies next.

 

The Book - iExperience

The book is written in 4 Parts.

Part 1 contains the Introduction + Chapters 1, 2, and 3. This chapter goes through the history of museums and how they became what they are today. You’ll learn about how museums were/are evolutionary in structure both physically and in ambiance. You’ll also learn about how experiential learning is the key to success and how pioneers like Walt Disney might have been an innovator in more industries than just one.

Part 2 contains Chapters 4, 5, and 6. Part 2 is an other-worldly part, as the reader is fully immersed in technology. You’ll see how technologies like virtual reality can be used not only as a new way to experience museums but also as a way for everyone to experience museums. Then, you’ll be immersed in Let’s Hopscotch: Light & Sound; a pop-up art exhibition that focuses on immersive, interactive experiences in order to bring people together and restore a once-lost connection.

Part 3 contains Chapters 7 and 8. This section focuses on expanding the demographics of museum-goers. Currently, the demographics of museum-goers revolves around women, ages 45-56— we need to change this. The question is: how? Through my own ethnographic and analytical research, you’ll learn that the key to getting more people to enjoy museums, or expanding the demographic, is through opening the doors to a new way of experiencing museums.

Part 4 contains chapters 9, 10, and the conclusion. The last part of my book focuses on exactly how we’re going to revitalize the museum industry. In March of 2019, I went to Austin’s SXSW— a city-wide festival, of sorts, about technology and innovation. Through my experience at the Trump’s Twitter Library exhibition, put on by The Daily Show, I saw exactly what needed to be done in order for this revitalization plan to work. Moreover, I focus-in on what the meaning of a museum truly is and how if that meaning is kept front and center, there’s no way a museum could fail.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 
  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in December 2019.
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter
  • When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.



I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book
  • And more...

 

About the Author

Madison Troutz is a University of Texas at Austin alum as well as a museum professional in Texas.

I wrote this book because I am passionate about museums. Through my formal education at UT, as a Sociocultural Anthropology major, it is in my nature to question environments and how they impact their inhabitants. As such, it only made sense to question the museum industry and take a visitor-centric approach when thinking about what they need in order to be future-proof.

If you were to ask my dog about me, he would probably say that his mom loves to go to local eateries and hit up local art events in the Austin area. However, I think that he’ll attest to, more than anything, my love for animals. As such, as an avid thrifter, I tend to only shop at thrift shops that give proceeds to local animal shelters. 

For more information, you can connect with Madison at madietroutz@gmail. LinkedIn https://www.linkedin.com/feed/, Instagram @madhaitro, and on her Website https://troutzhome.wixsite.com/website.

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family, and network. Please use #iExperience and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page

Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much for all of your love and support!

Thanks again,
Madison Troutz

A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book
And more...

 
About the Author
Madison Troutz is a University of Texas at Austin alum as well as a museum professional in Texas.I wrote this book because I am passionate about museums. Through my formal education at UT, as a Sociocultural Anthropology major, it is in my nature to question environments and how they impact their inhabitants. As such, it only made sense to question the museum industry and take a visitor-centric approach when thinking about what they need in order to be future-proof.If you were to ask my dog about me, he would probably say that his mom loves to go to local eateries and hit up local art events in the Austin area. However, I think that he’ll attest to, more than anything, my love for animals. As such, as an avid thrifter, I tend to only shop at thrift shops that give proceeds to local animal shelters. For more information, you can connect with Madison at madietroutz@gmail. LinkedIn https://www.linkedin.com/feed/, Instagram @madhaitro, and on her Website https://troutzhome.wixsite.com/website.
 
Risks & ChallengesThe biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship. 
Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family, and network. Please use #iExperience and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.
You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page
Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.
Thank you so much for all of your love and support!Thanks again,Madison Troutz

story:
My Book, Memoirs of Napoleon Streisand, is about the travel stories experienced and lessons learned when I traveled  to 7 continents in 4 months for only $241 in flight costs. It also teaches in depth of how to Travel Hack and get almost free airfare and free hotels around the world.

When I started my journey in 2013, the adventures lead me to swimming in Antarctica to hitch hiking around Argentina.  From the beaches of Thailand to the deserts of Egypt, the experiences shared from each country were life changing. The stories told about the trip were favored by many and suggested to be made into a book. Due to popular request, the book was written. 

the storeis from the trip would always be followed by "So...How can I travel the world for next to nothing in airfare?" That question is addressed in the book as well. The secrets and methods of Travel Hacking is shared of how to accumulate thousands(in my case, Millions) of Frequent Flyer Miles and hotel points with little effort. 

I want to share with the world what it was like to experience so many different cultures in a relatively short amount of time. From couchsurfing to staying fancy hotels (for free), my experience was very diverse. Trying my best to not be a tourist on this trip, I lived and experienced life as a local. Whenever possible, I would stay with locals of the countries visited.

It was a magnificent journey—the wonderful people I’ve met, the beautiful places I’ve seen, In short: My story traces my steps as I start my journey with a $3.75 flight to Uruguay to experience Carnival. I then hitch hiked through Patagonia, Argentina from where I caught a ship to Antarctica. From Chile to Australia to do a 10 day silent mediatation. I met up with my pregnant girlfriend, Christine, in South East Asia. I hung out with my friends in Africa and then to Europe. This brief but inexpensive trip costed me a whopping $241 in flights due to Travel Hacking. Travel Hacking is a way to democratize travelling; making it accessible to everyone. It involves hours of research and a bit of an analytical mind to use. Most travel hacking is about using miles and rewards to get free flights or hotels. It can easily be learned and I believe it must be shared with everyone who wants to travel.

Why did I write this book?

The main reason I am motivated to write this book for my daughter, Bella. I do not want to just tell her stories about my trip when she is older, I want to show her something tangible and make her think ”I have a cool Dad.” 

Why need money? Specifically, the invested funds will go toward: 

-Content Editing & Proof Reading

-Book Launch Marketing (Web & Traditional) 

-Technology Support for eBook Formatting 

-Printing & Distribution

 Spreading the Word: If you’d like to participate in the journey but can’t make a donation at this time, then please help get others involved. Share this campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter and everywhere else. Or send an email out to family and colleagues. The more people we get involved, the greater the impact on all our lives!

story:
Friends,

   As you may have heard, I was elected DNC District Delegate (Alternate) to the Democratic National Convention in Charolotte, NC. It is at the DNC Convention that we will nominate President Barack Obama for reelection. It is because of President Obama that we as a nation are on the verge of providing healthcare to millions of those less fortunate than us. President Obama is the reason that women sill have the right to choose what they feel is best for themselves, and Planned Parenthood is still able to provide care to millions of women, men, girls, and boys throughout the nation. And if not for Obama, our economy would still be in the tank. We must reelect our president.

 

   I am excited to be attending the convention in September, but the trip will not be cheap. Hotels, airfare, transportation and food add up quick. This is why I am calling on the community to contribute. I am asking everyone I know to donate to my effort, whatever they can. While I have included suggested donations, all amounts are appreciated. Will you contribute to my fund raising goal of $4500?

 

Wait! But what if Evan doesn't use all of the money he raises?? GREAT QUESTION! The extra will be split and donated to the California Young Democrats and the San Diego Democrats for Equality.

story:
Who We Are

thINKingDANCE launched in October 2011, co-founded by Lisa Kraus and Anna Drozdowski because Philly’s burgeoning dance scene needed more coverage—intelligent, respectful writing—especially with the decline in print journalism. With 21 writers out of the starting gate and now 8 more, we have published over 260 articles about the work of over 150 artists/companies/venues. Our first year’s workshops, website design, and writer and editor fees were supported by a Dance Advance grant. Since January, we’ve been donating our time. To create a sustainable future, we need to pay our people! We are raising $8000 through Indiegogo and we look to you and everyone who reads and benefits from TD to partner with us by contributing your support.

 

More reasons to give and perks for every level of donation are listed below.  

 

Thank you for reading and supporting thINKingDANCE!

Amelia Longo, Anna Drozdowski, Anne Wilson, Becca Weber, Carolyn Merritt, Christina Gesualdi, Debbie Shapiro, Ellen Gerdes, James Rutter, Jonathan Stein, Julie Diana, Kalila Kingsford Smith, Kariamu Welsh,  Kirsten Kaschock,  Kristen Gillette, Lisa Bardarson, Lisa Kraus, Lynn M. Brooks, Lynnette Overby, Megan Bridge, Nathaniel B. Hancock, Patricia Graham, Peter Price, R. Eric Thomas, Whitney Weinstein

What We Need

Here’s where the money will go:

  • Workshops with guest teachers to develop skills in seeing, writing and critiquing  $1500

  • Web upgrades $500

  • Writers and editors fees  $4500

  • Fees for our editorial board, coordination of workshops and assignments, and social media, communications and grant-writing   $1500  

 

We'll thank you with gifts for various levels of giving that include public thanks on our site and on Facebook,  the unique TD lapel pin, the chance to curate your own Public Square discussion, a “Dance Date” attending a show with a TD writer, sitting in on our workshops, and more.


At TD, we imagined a future for dance writing. It looked something like this:

 

What if dance writing had a space that was more than 3 column inches?

 

What if writers came together to talk about their craft, the field and the work they saw?

 

What if choreographers could rely on getting coverage for their work that digs deeper, that doesn’t just describe?

 

What if our city’s thriving, growing dance scene was made more visible, both in and outside of Philadelphia?

 

Over the last year and a half, thINKingDANCE has been working on creating that future. We’ve had a slow, quiet, but volcanic impact.

 

What People Are Saying:

 

  • Terry Fox, Executive Director, Philadelphia Dance Projects:

“Anyone who writes about dance revs up the excitement for it and the discussion around it, or so that has been the result of thINKingDANCE  among dancers and presenters here in the Philly area the past 2 years. Preview articles have served to promote events and attract audience by linking to Facebook, websites and e-news.  Overall the journal has tangibly demonstrated the large volume of dance activity going in the region and has provided a history for same, which in and of itself is a valuable service to a somewhat marginalized art form. TD has trained and given voice to many people wanting to pursue esthetic and critical writing.”

 

  • Nicole Bindler, Choreographer

“TD broadens the accessibility of dance for the layperson, exposing audiences to the underlying concepts and ideas that dance artists are working with. TD supports dance artists in Philadelphia by providing a mirror to reflect on their work, a new lens through which to see their process and by giving them a vital presence online... When I was in residence in Mexico City a musician noticed I was reading Susan Rethorst's book and then said: "Ahh, I've heard about this..." and then showed me a tab on his web browser with Megan Bridge's TD review of the book.How did a musician in Mexico find his way there? How many others around the world are reading about dance through TD and expanding their definition and impression of what dance is?"

 

  • Nathea Lee, Managing Director, Kùlú Mèlé African Dance & Drum Ensemble

“As a managing director and member of Philadelphia's rich dance community, I appreciate thINKingDANCE for its thoughtful and well informed coverage of the full spectrum of dance. It is especially meaningful at this time when media coverage of arts and culture has diminished to such an extent. There are not many writers who are knowledgeable about traditional/folkloric dance, so it has been refreshing to read reviews of Kulu Mele's work that are written from an informed perspective.”

 

  • Marissa Montenegro, Public Relations Manager, Pennsylvania Ballet   

  “Since its inception, thINKingDANCE has offered an invaluable platform for both the city’s talented dance writers as well as its vibrant and diverse dance organizations and artists. Its writers have crafted countless thoughtful, creative, and meaningful pieces. Their contribution to the discourse on dance in Philadelphia cannot be overstated.”

 

Many projects you’re asked to support have start and end dates. We’re here, serving you all year long. Just like public radio you can access us for free, but also like public radio, we’re asking readers who value what we do to step up and do your share. Only you can say what TD is worth to you. Let us know through your contribution.

 

thINKingDANCE by the Numbers

 

18 months into the project we have written about

154 Artists/Groups/Presenters in

293 original reviews, features, news items, Public Squares and letters. We're read by people in  

129 countries including

3 in Senegal

23 in Saudi Arabia and

38,950 from all over the US. We’ve held professional development workshops with

9 master writers/dramaturgs/artists for

29 writers from all walks of life including a public interest lawyer, a principal ballerina, arts administrators, an anthropologist and more.

 

Help us keep thinking and writing about dance by making your donation today!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help us by:

  • Sharing this campaign with friends and asking them to support us too

  • Using the Indiegogo share tools

  • Reposting pieces you like from the TD site

  • Weighing in on anything you want to comment on

     

Thank you so much!

story:
Merci à tous de nous avoir permis d'ameber cette campagne à terme.

Thank you for helping us successfully finish this campaign!

(Complete English overview is provided at http://www.awayfromafrica.com/2013/05/from-hut-to-modern-home-book-campaign.html)

Note: For English-language subscribers ($35 up), we will prepare a shortened digital version of the book, in English, by the time the book is published.
“From the Hut to the Modern Home” is a discussion and analysis of the evolution of housing in African architecture from traditional dwellings to the modern home.

Subjects covered in the book include:

-Historical migrations in Africa

-Traditional architecture in Cameroon

-Colonial architecture

-The consequences of social changes on architecture and construction

-The evolution of housing in Cameroon

-Thoughts on the future of African architecture.

De la Case à la Villa traite du concept d'habiter dans l'architecture africaine.

Pourquoi ce livre?

Il existe peu d'ouvrages qui expliquent les liens entre l'histoire, la colonisation, la sociologie et l'architecture en Afrique. L'importance de ce livre réside dans le fait qu'il couvre les conséquences des changements structuraux de la société en Afrique Centrale sur le logement, tout en décrivant les techniques traditionnelles, le tout abondamment illustré, avec des photos et des dessins.

Cet ouvrage est une tentative de réponse au dilemme constant que rencontre l'architecte africain, dans sa pratique du métier, à savoir la conception des architectures "africaines modernes" alors que les africains ne veulent plus vivre dans des cases ou des huttes de paille.

La démarche que propose Epée Ellong, avec Diane Chehab, est de parcourir ce qui constitue l'architecture africaine traditionnelle jusqu'à l'architecture africaine moderne, afin de faire apparaître les contradictions dans les mutations sociales et techniques au cours des différentes étapes historiques qui constituent cette époque. 

Pour accomplir ce travail, l'auteur puise dans son expérience et sa connaissance propre de l'Afrique Centrale. Il a voyagé considérablement à l'intérieur du Cameroun, et a discuté avec les habitants, y inclus les chefs traditionnels et les anciens des villages.

Les illustrations et photos qui accompagnent les textes montrent les phases de construction des architectures traditionnelles, modernes, les objets usuels, etc... De nombreuses références historiques et linguistiques vernaculaires sont utilisées pour mieux expliquer et faire comprendre les changements sur le plan humain et architectural.

Parmi les sujets couverts dans l’ouvrage:

- Les migrations historiques en Afrique

- L’architecture traditionnelle au Cameroun

- L’architecture coloniale

- Les conséquences des changements sociaux sur l’architecture et l’espace bâti

- L’évolution de l’habitat au Cameroun

- Orientations pour une architecture

Nos besoins pour publier ce livre:

Nous avons besoin d'un minimum de $9000 (environ 6800 Euros) pour éditer, revoir la maquette, et imprimer le livre, qui fera (la maquette n'est pas finalisée) environ 230 pages en A4, avec de nombreuses illustrations en couleur. Nous proposons, selon la somme promise, des signets illustrés, le livre, le livre dédicacé, voire votre nom mentionné dans le livre. 

Les auteurs

Epée Ellong: Né au Cameroun, Epée Ellong poursuit des études d’architecture aux Beaux Arts à Paris, France. Après ses études, il rentre au Cameroun et crée un cabinet d’architecture avec son épouse, Diane Chehab, architecte américaine. Les projets du cabinet l’amènent à voyager dans différentes régions de l'Afrique Centrale et du Cameroun, et le familiarisent avec la diversité ethnique, culturelle et géographique du pays. Par la suite il rencontre plusieurs chefs traditionnels de ces régions, qui sont une grande source d’information sur les changements sociologiques et architecturaux intervenus avec l'arrivée des Européens. Il élabore avec eux une nomenclature en langue autochtone des éléments typologiques de la construction traditionnelle. Depuis 1995, Epée exerce l'architecture aux Etats Unis. Il enseigne également l'architecture "Afrocentrique" dans le cadre d’ateliers spécialisés, et présente son travail dans des universités américaines et au « Museum for African Art » à New York.

Diane Chehab: Née aux Etats-Unis, Diane Chehab a vécu sur plusieurs continents et a suivi des études d’architecture à l’Université Libanaise à Beyrouth, et aux Beaux Arts à Paris, en France. Ayant épousé son collègue Epée Ellong, elle rentre avec lui au Cameroun, et gère leur cabinet d’architecture. Elle apprend la langue Duala de son mari pour mieux appréhender la culture locale. Diane vit aux Etats-Unis avec son époux.

Merci de nous aider dans ce projet... 

Nous apprécierons énormément si vous pouvez faire passer le mot pour cette campagne aux personnes de votre entourage.

  • Faire suivre par email, Twitter, Facebook, etc.
  • Utilisez les outils fournis par Indiegogo!

Nous vous en remercions d'avance.

Note: Les dates et d'autres détails se préciseront une fois la campagne terminée. Si vous avez des questions, veuillez nous écrire à Padouk@padoukdesign.com.

Graphisme couverture: Melville Sylvester

Nous avons besoin d'un minimum de $9000 (environ 6800 Euros) pour éditer, revoir la maquette, et imprimer le livre, qui fera (la maquette n'est pas finalisée) environ 230 pages en A4, avec de nombreuses illustrations en couleur. Nous proposons, selon la somme promise, des signets illustrés, le livre, le livre dédicacé, voire votre nom mentionné dans le livre. 
Les auteurs



Epée Ellong: Né au Cameroun, Epée Ellong poursuit des études d’architecture aux Beaux Arts à Paris, France. Après ses études, il rentre au Cameroun et crée un cabinet d’architecture avec son épouse, Diane Chehab, architecte américaine. Les projets du cabinet l’amènent à voyager dans différentes régions de l'Afrique Centrale et du Cameroun, et le familiarisent avec la diversité ethnique, culturelle et géographique du pays. Par la suite il rencontre plusieurs chefs traditionnels de ces régions, qui sont une grande source d’information sur les changements sociologiques et architecturaux intervenus avec l'arrivée des Européens. Il élabore avec eux une nomenclature en langue autochtone des éléments typologiques de la construction traditionnelle. Depuis 1995, Epée exerce l'architecture aux Etats Unis. Il enseigne également l'architecture "Afrocentrique" dans le cadre d’ateliers spécialisés, et présente son travail dans des universités américaines et au « Museum for African Art » à New York.
 Diane Chehab: Née aux Etats-Unis, Diane Chehab a vécu sur plusieurs continents et a suivi des études d’architecture à l’Université Libanaise à Beyrouth, et aux Beaux Arts à Paris, en France. Ayant épousé son collègue Epée Ellong, elle rentre avec lui au Cameroun, et gère leur cabinet d’architecture. Elle apprend la langue Duala de son mari pour mieux appréhender la culture locale. Diane vit aux Etats-Unis avec son époux.
Merci de nous aider dans ce projet... 



Nous apprécierons énormément si vous pouvez faire passer le mot pour cette campagne aux personnes de votre entourage.

Faire suivre par email, Twitter, Facebook, etc.
Utilisez les outils fournis par Indiegogo!


Nous vous en remercions d'avance.
Note: Les dates et d'autres détails se préciseront une fois la campagne terminée. Si vous avez des questions, veuillez nous écrire à Padouk@padoukdesign.com.
Graphisme couverture: Melville Sylvester

story:
Hello. 

This project helps fight childhood cancer, supports independent artists, and entertains you. And it's ridiculously simple.

I'm Rick Wayne, and I'm a socially responsible author.

That doesn't mean I write about the environment or social justice. It means I want to make the act of reading a social good (not just a personal one).

I want you to help the world even when you're enjoying amazing stories about wizards or counter-terrorists or renegade lovers or explosions in space.

I mean, why can't we enjoy ourselves and be socially conscious at the same time?

I think we can.

But I can't do it alone.

I'm organizing an anthology of eclectic short fiction for release later this year. The authors will all be talented independents writing cutting-edge stories on all kinds of crazy ideas (not just socially conscious ones).

Here's where you come in.

The business end of a book, much like the business end of a horse, is an active and smelly thing. It takes a lot of feed to write, edit, cover design, format, and produce an awesome book.

And we're going for awesome here.

I'll cull the best in indie short fiction, have it professionally edited, and deliver awesomeness to your door... that is, if you're willing to help.

Here's why you should, why this project is different:

First, you get something right now, a novella called Agony in Violet, and you get to keep it whether we meet our goal or not. (Some of you may have it already!)

Second, all proceeds from the ongoing sale of the finished anthology will go to St. Jude's Children's Hospital, because I believe there's nothing more awesome than helping sick kids. Period.

There are lots of worthy projects out there, I know. But I'm not aware of any that make your dollar do so much at once.

I hope you'll support this project, and have fun too.

Be Good. And happy reading. :)

(and if you want to hear more about what you get, keep scrolling...)

 

Why support St. Jude?

From the website...

The support of caring people like you helps ensure that St. Jude Children's Research Hospital will continue its lifesaving mission of finding cures and saving children.

How do your donations help?

  • Thanks to donors, no family ever pays St. Jude for anything. Care, housing, transportation, meals—the list of services we provide to our families is unequalled. But it is for one purpose: To ensure the very best outcome possible for every child.

How is St. Jude making a difference for sick children?

  • Every child saved at St. Jude means children saved around the world—a direct result of cutting-edge research and treatment that set the standard in treating childhood cancers. And our discoveries are shared freely with doctors and scientists all over the world.

How are donations used?

  • During the past five years, 81 cents of every dollar received has supported the research and treatment at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital.
  • It costs $1.8 million a day to operate St. Jude, and public donations provide more than 75 percent of our funding.

www.stjude.org

 

Who Am I?

These days I spend most of my time writing fictional oddities, but in previous lives I've been a medical student, a survey researcher, a corporate executive, and a husband.

I have two big dogs that go with me everywhere. I'm a cheese freak, a music junkie, and an art fanatic.

I also try to be a good person. 2012 was a very hard year for me and my family. Marriages ended. Jobs were lost. Health declined. It was tough.

But we got through that, and now I'd like to give something back. Will you help?

Whether you donate or not, I'd love to hear from you. Send me a note and tell me what you think of this project at:

rick@dreadfulcafe.com

 

 

Why Not Just Give to St. Jude Directly?

You could, and that would be great. Here is the link where you can make that donation:

 

https://shop.stjude.org/GiftCatalog/donation.do?cID=14222&pID=23750

However, if you donate to this project, I will add blood, sweat, and elbow grease to turn your donation into something greater--not only a greater donation down the road, but a new model where readers and writers come together to make the world a better place just by doing what they enjoy.

In short, your donation here is the ripple that starts the wave!

 

Why Support Crowdfunded Reading?

Writing projects typically do very poorly on crowdfunding sites. In fact, publishing ranks second-to-last on overall funding success rate.

Some might argue that's because people don't read anymore, but I don't think that's it.

It's easy to hear a sample of someone's music or look at a concept sketch for a new graphic novel and decide if you'll like it or not.

But if I tell you, "these stories are going to be awesome!" you'll naturally be skeptical, and there's no easy way for me convince you this project is worth your money.

And so your dollar goes to other cool projects.

 

Why an Anthology?

It's like finding new music. The hardest part is knowing where to look and who to trust.

There has been an EXPLOSION of indie writers in the last few years. The market is flooded. I think we all know there is some really good stuff out there. But how do you find it?

That's my job. Think of this anthology like a new music sampler. You probably won't love everything, but you'll at least find a few new authors that really speak to you.

Go find those author's other works, and now you've got a month's worth of additional awesome reading, or more.

 

How Will It Work?

First, we need to hit our goal. That has to be step one. And please don't assume that will just magically happen without your help, 'cuz it won't.

Second, thank you for being a nice person. It counts. And I notice it.

Third, once funded, I will get the word out through my network of fellow authors that we're accepting submissions between 3,000 and 30,000 words. This is paid work, so I know we'll get a massive response! I'll sift through the roughage and find 8-12 diamonds. I will then set the authors to work with an experienced fiction editor to polish, polish, polish and produce a real professional piece.

I will hire a talented cover artist, secure a limited print run, and deliver gold-plated awesomeness to your door. And you don't have to lift a finger.

While you're enjoying the stories, I will sell the remainder of the books to fund additional printing as necessary to cover future sales. I will also market the book online and at conventions, bookstores, coffee shops, concerts, churches, tattoo parlors, slaughterhouses, carnivals, and anywhere else good people like to hang out.

All the after-cost proceeds go to charity for as long as the book will sell.

 

Where Will My Money Go?

The short answer: to the artists, to overhead, to the kids. That's it.

Here's a quick break down:

~$3,600 to pay 8-12 artists a fair price for their work

+$2,000 for multiple rounds of professional editing

+$500 to pay for the creation of and license to great cover art

+$2,300 for formatting and a very limited print run

+$1,000 to cover campaign costs (indiegogo, PayPal, etc.)

+$800 in basic marketing expenses (such as listing the book, printing flyers, renting booth space, etc.) so people know to buy it for a worthy cause!

Minus $500 of my own money that I am putting up to support this project.

$9,700 Total

Obviously all of that is an approximation, but it's a good approximation based on professional experience. If anything, it's a little low.

In the very unlikely event we are over-funded--that more people pledge than are required to produce the work--the money will go to expand the print run so we can sell more to support St. Jude.

Let's kick some butt! 

Image courtesy of Kim Herbst

www.kimherbst.com

 

Secret basement offer: This project is important to me. So important, I'll email you the novella for any pledge at all, even a dollar, although I hope you'll consider more.

story:
Short Summary

Welcome to my campaign. A Saudi Life is a fictional novel that I have had in my head for a few years now and never got around to get it out. Its basically the story of Saudi man and his friends starting with high school in the 90s all the way to today. While its fictional it does get much of its inspiration from my personal life and the lives of my family and friends. In the novel we explore Saudi Arabia and the evolution of culture and politics starting with the end of the Gulf war to the Arab spring. This is basically an insider story of the Saudi culture.

The Author

I'm a 37 year old male native of Saudi Arabia. I was born and raised in Riyadh and have spent about 12 years of my life abroad either as a child or an adult. I've been happily married for the last 2 and a half years to a great and supportive local doctor. Some of you might know me from my old podcasts. A Saudi Life was a podcast hosted and produced by me talking about Saudi Arabia and its culture. I also had the pleasure to guest a number of time on The Phileas Club podcast.

What I Need

I have always wanted to write this novel but never had the energy or the time to do so. As this has been long overdue and thinking about it is taking more energy then just writing it I decided it was time to do it. However, I am not a writer, I'm just a person with a story which means I would need a professional editor  to work with me on this project. I estimate that this would cost around USD5000 at minimum. 

What You Get

Please check the perks to the right -->

The Impact

For many Saudi Arabia is a mystery and for some their knowledge of Saudi Arabia is limited, even those that visit or live in Saudi Arabia from the western expat community don't always get to know Saudi Arabia and their knowledge is limited to a specific part of society, the western educated middle and upper class or the tourist view. Very few people outside of Saudi Arabia experience or understand Saudi culture from a family perspective on many levels and no better way to learn about Saudi then to read it in a novel. This is a fictional novel so its meant as entertaiment first but its also meant to introduce Saudi culture from the perspective of a Saudi and its important to give a true image about the culture its self.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and inform your friends and family about this project and let your social network know about it.

Sample

I am working on two approaches to a novel, one is Sci-Fi futuristic view of Saudi Arabia, this would be my next project. For this funding I want to work on the story of a local saudi man starting in 1992 with the gulf war and his days in high school up to current time. The following is an extremely rough draft of the first couple of pages. This is only to give an idea of what I'm doing, it is in no way an example of what the final product would be.

"
It's a new year and I’m back to school transferring to my first year in secondary school. Its been a hard last year, Saddams Armies invaded Kuwait and all hell broke loss. Saudi Arabia has been in a state of war for the first time in its history since its unification in 1932. Life has been weird and crazy the last year with schools closed most of the time and people moving all around the country trying to move away from the range of the scud missiles Sadam unleashed on us, recruitment camps for volunteers 16 years or older were established under the pressure and demand of the population to play a part in defending the country, the patriotic fever has reached its ultimest level in the country. Thousands of Kuwaiti refugees moved to Saudi including the royal family. This also coincided with the deployment of  US forces in Saudi as a major part of the international coalition to protect Saudi and liberate Kuwait, which didn’t go smoothly with many Saudis who saw it either as a symbol of weakness to depend on others or saw it as an invasion of infidels to the holy lands. But little did the Saudi government have an option in the matter, Saudi forces were small compared to irags one million man force and with little to no real combat experience compared to Iraqs 7 year war experience with Iran, plus Iraq was massing an assault on the Saudi Kuwaiti boarders, at least that’s what the US and their satellite photos claimed, if you ask some till this day they would tell you those photos were brushed and the iraqi forces were building defenses and not an assault, but that’s the past and what happened happened.
Oh ya I forgot, let me introduce my self. My name is Faisal AlKhalidy from Saudi Arabia, born and raised in Riyadh city but my family originally descends from the Qassim region just north of Riyadh city. I’m 16 years old and starting my first year in secondary school I guess its called high school in the USA. My father is Naseer AlKhalidy an accountant for the Ministry of Defense, my mother is Haia AlMishary a house wife and a great mother. I have three brothers and one sister. I’m the oldest in the family. We live in one of Riyadh's modern middle class neighborhoods in the north called AlOliya. I love it here it’s a bit more modern then the rest of Riyadh with more of a western style. Our house is decent and average for a middle class family. Its about 650 square meters with a small guardin, a room for the chufer, 5 bedrooms, mens guest living room, women guest living room, family living room, dinning room, kitchen, and 6 bathrooms.
Man I miss summer vacation, waking up so early is no fun, “Mom close those curtness the light is annoying” I shout out as my mother enters my room and opens the curtness to let the sun light in and wake me up. “Its 6 am and the drive to school takes half an hour so get out of bed and get ready it’s a school day not a vacation anymore.” she says that as she turns the AC off and exits my room and continues her morning routine of waking me and my brothers and sister up. 6 am, man I got used to sleeping in till 12 pm if I wanted. I start to lazily move out of bed, man its cold that AC works great at night. I finally get out of bed and head to the bathroom. I look into the mirror and man do I look horrible, I got so used at staying up late during summer that I didn’t sleep till 2 am last night. I brush my teeth and wash up and then perform wodu, woudu is a ritual washing that muslims need to perform before praying, start out with washing the hands, followed by the mouth then the nose, the face, arms. hair and ears and finally the feet. I didn’t wake up to perform the fajer (sunrise) prayer today so better late then never. I exit the bathroom and there on my desk I find a hot glass of milk, I guess the maid brought it in while I was washing up. My mom has gotten us used to having a glass of milk every morning just before school. I’ll just let it cool down a bit while I pray and change into my school clothes. Its nice to have your own room, I feel sorry for Ali and Saad, my youngest two brothers, they have to share a room together and do they fight a lot. Ya I got my own room with a bathroom, Fahad the oldest of my brothers has his own room but shares the bathroom with Ali and Saad, Nora my sister has her own bedroom with a bathroom because shes the only girl even though shes the youngest. Of-course my mom and dad have their own room as well. I finish praying and head to the closet where I get my clothes for school out. Well nothing special for school, we wear what we usually wear everyday here in Saudi a thob and a somaq. A thob is like a shirt that is body length usually white specially during summer and a somag is a cloth that we wear on our heads. Its traditional Saudi clothes, we also usually wear an uqal to hold the somaq to our heads but its baned in school as some students used it as a weapon, an oqal is like a thick circular rope and can be painful if you hit someone with it. After I get my clothes on I check my bag, got a notebook and pencils, hope we get our books today. I drink my milk and exit my room. In the family living room I find my mom relaxing and having a cup of coffee, my dad is still asleep he won’t wake up for another hour. I head to my mom kiss her forehead and sit down beside her as we wait for the rest of my brothers and sister to come down."

Timeframe

The plan is to publish the book by the end of 2014. It might happen sooner but I rather give myself a years worth of flexibility.

Risks and challenges

There are two main challenges, one is the finding the right editor to help with the book. The second is writing the book, this is a challenge for any writer. I do intend to get this book written and published, reaching the funding goal means it will happen in 2014.

FAQ

Please ask in the comment section or by email saudi@asaudilife.net I will respond to all comments and questions as time permits and will post questions and answers here as I receive them.

Its about 650 square meters with a small guardin, a room for the chufer, 5 bedrooms, mens guest living room, women guest living room, family living room, dinning room, kitchen, and 6 bathrooms.Man I miss summer vacation, waking up so early is no fun, “Mom close those curtness the light is annoying” I shout out as my mother enters my room and opens the curtness to let the sun light in and wake me up. “Its 6 am and the drive to school takes half an hour so get out of bed and get ready it’s a school day not a vacation anymore.” she says that as she turns the AC off and exits my room and continues her morning routine of waking me and my brothers and sister up. 6 am, man I got used to sleeping in till 12 pm if I wanted. I start to lazily move out of bed, man its cold that AC works great at night. I finally get out of bed and head to the bathroom. I look into the mirror and man do I look horrible, I got so used at staying up late during summer that I didn’t sleep till 2 am last night. I brush my teeth and wash up and then perform wodu, woudu is a ritual washing that muslims need to perform before praying, start out with washing the hands, followed by the mouth then the nose, the face, arms. hair and ears and finally the feet. I didn’t wake up to perform the fajer (sunrise) prayer today so better late then never. I exit the bathroom and there on my desk I find a hot glass of milk, I guess the maid brought it in while I was washing up. My mom has gotten us used to having a glass of milk every morning just before school. I’ll just let it cool down a bit while I pray and change into my school clothes. Its nice to have your own room, I feel sorry for Ali and Saad, my youngest two brothers, they have to share a room together and do they fight a lot. Ya I got my own room with a bathroom, Fahad the oldest of my brothers has his own room but shares the bathroom with Ali and Saad, Nora my sister has her own bedroom with a bathroom because shes the only girl even though shes the youngest. Of-course my mom and dad have their own room as well. I finish praying and head to the closet where I get my clothes for school out. Well nothing special for school, we wear what we usually wear everyday here in Saudi a thob and a somaq. A thob is like a shirt that is body length usually white specially during summer and a somag is a cloth that we wear on our heads. Its traditional Saudi clothes, we also usually wear an uqal to hold the somaq to our heads but its baned in school as some students used it as a weapon, an oqal is like a thick circular rope and can be painful if you hit someone with it. After I get my clothes on I check my bag, got a notebook and pencils, hope we get our books today. I drink my milk and exit my room. In the family living room I find my mom relaxing and having a cup of coffee, my dad is still asleep he won’t wake up for another hour. I head to my mom kiss her forehead and sit down beside her as we wait for the rest of my brothers and sister to come down."
Timeframe
The plan is to publish the book by the end of 2014. It might happen sooner but I rather give myself a years worth of flexibility.

Risks and challenges
There are two main challenges, one is the finding the right editor to help with the book. The second is writing the book, this is a challenge for any writer. I do intend to get this book written and published, reaching the funding goal means it will happen in 2014.FAQPlease ask in the comment section or by email saudi@asaudilife.net I will respond to all comments and questions as time permits and will post questions and answers here as I receive them.

story:
Who is Dusty Pierre and what is the story about?

Dusty Pierre is quite the unusual robot. His curiosity takes him on thrilling adventures across the galaxy. In our first story, called "Dusty Pierre's Secret Search of Love," Dusty wants to experience first-hand this feeling humans call love and it takes him on a secret mission to Earth to a city called Paris. Along the way, he experiences a variety of new feelings including sadness, joy, frustration, disappointment, perseverance and ultimately, love.  If you have a few minutes to watch our short video, you can see, in more detail, what the story is about.  We envision an entire series of short stories around Dusty Pierre's adventures.  This is only the beginning!

Who is behind this project?

Hi.  My name is Troy Green.  My passion for writing short stories and working with artists was discovered about three years ago as a hobby, while working in a career on the complete opposite side of the spectrum as a business analyst. Evenings and weekends were spent exploring this interest and although it started out as a hobby, just recently I realized how much pleasure this brought to my life and decided to take a huge leap out of the corporate world to follow my dreams of writing short stories full-time. Along the way, I have been fortunate enough to meet a special artist named Ivo Kozarov. His extraordinary artistic skills, hard work, and ability to understand my vision of characters and storylines is a huge reason why we have come this far. Both of us have worked together for the past year in building a portfolio of around 50 unique robot and alien characters as well as our first short story called “Dusty Pierre’s Secret Search of Love”. We hope this campaign can launch us into the world of creating and self-publishing children’s books.

 

Why Indiegogo

We’ve applied a great deal of time building “Dusty Pierre’s Secret Search of Love,” creating more than 25+ scenes.  We carefully depict each scene to fit and flow with the storyline.  Most of the scenes are currently only sketches. To turn this into a completed story with full illustrations and self-publish as a paperback book, will require a lot more time. If we are fortunate enough to gather enough funds from this campaign, we want to turn Dusty Pierre’s first adventure to life and self-publish our first paperback book. The paperback book will ultimately include over 40+ pages. Indiegogo provides us an opportunity to potentially gather enough funds to continue this exciting venture.

What We Need

Our goal for this campaign is to raise at least $20,000.  Keep in mind that 40-45% of total funds will actually be used for costs of gifts for our generous supporters, particulalry books, while another 9% of costs will go to Indiegogo, unless of course we meet our goal.  Because total costs of the campaign will be around 55% of total funds, the first $8,000 of campaign funds will be used to help pay for the fantastic illustration work Ivo will do to complete the book.  After costs of the first $8,000 of funds, that leaves me around $3,700 to pay for illustration work. Every dollar past the first $8,000 of funds wil go directly towards print costs to build a small inventory of books that will be used for local bookstores around the San Francisco Bay area. 

To give you an idea of the time needed for illustration work, each of the 25-30 color illustrations for the book can take many hours to create from start to finish. It's a fairly demanding task, especially given the short time frame to complete.  We will then convert each of the illustrations and storyline into a printer friendly format for books.

Longer term, we hope to turn "The Adventures of Dusty Pierre" into a popular series with added accompaniments such as coloring books, action figures, games, stickers, posters, bedroom/bathroom sets, and hopefully someday, short animated films. But for now, we are focused on getting our first book published and we are grateful for anything you can provide. Our dream is to do this full-time. Not just a career, but as an adventure!

What if we don't meet our goal?

First and foremost I want to pay Ivo for his fantastic illustration work, that is the number one goal.   All funds under $8,000 will help me pay for illustration work.  Any dollar above $8,000 will go towards building a small inventory of our first book.

Stretch Goals

If we are fortunate and lucky enough to surpass our initial goal of $20,000, the funds will go directly towards developing our second book called "Dusty Pierre and Guapo Chop It Up!". The storyline takes place back on the space ship where Dusty decides to take a sushi cooking class with master chef El Guapo and his mini chefs.  During the cooking class Dusty gets distracted with using chop sticks to attempt catching a fly.  One of the mini chefs takes this personally and gives Dusty the glare.  A few minutes later Dusty again attempts to catch a fly and the mini chef is now upset.  El Guapo, the big chef steps in and ultimately turns into a brief chop stick fight.  

My dream is to do this venture full-time working with a variety of talented artists from all over the world, building multiple storylines, characters, games, and merchandise around each of the storylines.  10-15 years from now I want to be in direct competition with Disney.  I believe stretch goals for this are out of reach and unrealistic, but if we somehow manage to exceed $40,000 this would fullfill my dream of pursing this venture full-time.

Why not go to a publishing house?

Although working with a publishing house is a great option for many writers, they tend to give very little control and ownership to original writers and illustrators. Since we are completely new to the industry, we will have little negotiating leverage with potential publishing houses on ownership and commission rates. They also have full control over pricing and marketing strategies.

We not only want the ability to build relationships with local bookstores, but also to have full control over pricing of our books at any time, particularly for marketing efforts during seasonal time frames and discounting. This can only be accomplished by following the path of self-publishing!

Why not ebooks?

There has always been something about the look and feel of a real tangible copy of a children’s book. We believe the world is in need of new children’s books in hardback and paperback form, and that is what we want to focus our efforts on. Longer term, we plan to go digital, but our dream is to produce real books for kids to flip through the pages and hold!

Other characters in our portfolio

Below are some more characters we've created, but aren't yet included in storylines.  We want to turn these to life someday too!

Shipping

Researching shipping costs for different places around the world has turned out to be a little more complicated than I anticipated and I decided to keep costs of shipping separate. My apologies in advance for the inconvenience. 

Limited 1st Edition Print

All three limited 1st edition books will only be printed and distributed as gifts for this campaign, so no other 1st edition books will ever be printed and sold again.

Closing Words

THANK YOU ALL for your generous gifts, it means a great deal.  We are grateful for any contribution, even if it's just passing on the campaign to someone else that might be interested in supporting the cause.

All the best!

Our website is www.dustypierre.com.  For the time being the domain name is forwarding on to the Indiegogo campaign.

Sincerely,

The Dusty Pierre Team

story:
INTRODUCTION TO JUDY

Dr. Judith Shepard Gomez has spent her entire professional career and personal life devoted to helping others work towards becoming more open, accepting and honoring of people of diverse  backgrounds.  She is passionate about inclusion, and  as  Professor of Sociology, a Professional Mediator and a Meditation Teacher, has pioneered Workshops for small and large groups that are designed to raise awareness of the challenges of inclusiveness, and explore the paths towards personal and  group transformation.  

She lives in the Southwest with her long term partner,  whom she officially married on March 30th of this year.  They have three adult  children, two Sons in Law, one Fiancée, and 10 Grandchildren ranging in age from  5-24.  She has lived the experience captured in this powerful book and is passionate about   creating the moment for others to heal division, and nurture understanding, strength and love.


BRIEF DESCRIPTION OF CAMPAIGN

"Mia's Two Grammas--a child's coming out Story" is a children's picture book for ages 2-10. In 32 pages, it tells the story of Mia struggling with the dilemma of whether to bring Gay Grandmas to Grandparents day at her school.

The money from this campaign will be used to accomplish as many of the the following  goals as possible.  We feel strongly that each goal is an essential  part of the process of helping diverse families to reach out to each other, and to others, to share who they are with strength and pride.

1. Hire an Illustrator to capture the essence of the story in a way that is easily engaging to children, parents, Grandparents, teachers.

2. Self Publish the Book in a large enough volume to allow distribution throughout the United States, in both urban and rural area.

3. Design and publish a Website and a mobile App that will encourage interactive discovery on themes of inclusion, resilience, family diversity, and inter-generational understanding and acceptance

4. It will allow Dr. Gomez to hire an illustrator, print hard cover deluxe editions of the book,  build a distribution network, and, if possible, begin the process of translation into other languages for families in other countries where Gay marriage, and Gay Grandparents live and struggle to share their lives openly with their own children and grandchildren.( Spanish, French, Hebrew will be the first  translations)

5.Design and implementation of a series of Workshops on Nurturing Inclusive Families that can be offered to schools,  religious communities, YMCAs and other community institutions

6.  Write and  Publish books on    diverse families.  In fact we envision a series called “The Gramma Chronicles” in which each book  is based on a family with  different ethnic, religious, cultural heritage.


WHY THIS IS IMPORTANT

I have lived the experience in this book many times with my Grandchildren and their friends.  Although there are a few books (very few) that introduce and  explore the world of families with Gay parents, there are none with Gay Grandparents as the focus.  In todays world, children spend many years in very deep and close contact with their grandparents, yet they have no children's books to help open the dialogue about any challenges they, the children, may face in “coming out” to their friends about their special and unique family.  This Book was written to be just such a point of conversation, tears, growth, bonding, resilience builder.


HOW SUPPORT WILL HELP

Your support will make all of the above possible. It will provide the much needed funds to hire and illustrator,  self publish the book and an accompanying workbook, and website, and enable Dr. Gomez to travel to cities other than her own to give readings, lead workshops, build community with other special but different families of all kinds.

If we raise $10,000 we can do the publishing. If we raise 15,000 we can     create and publish the Website,  If we raise $20,000 we can distribute it  all over the country, reaching  parents, children and Grandchildren in areas where they may at this time feel completely isolated and not know where to turn for help in building resilience in their own families and those of their friends and neighbors.

We deeply appreciate your support and your help.

story:
About Me

I'm a queer, disabled, mestiza travel writer, photographer and editor from Brooklyn by way of Ecuador who has been transient for about 11 years. I fund my adventures by crafting non-commercial indie travel media at the crux of race, place and adventure, but for the past 3 years, all my cash saved from dead-end jobs has gone to paying for my extensive medical care.

About VONA

VONA/Voices is the nation's only multi-genre workshop for writers of color, and I'm lucky to have been accepted to join in this June! I come from a single-parent, working-class, immigrant household in New York, and opportunities like this are rare, Even if I had finished high school and gone to college, I still wouldn't have gotten a writing coach of color who focuses on travel! Spaces like these are really important for people like me in this white, straight, male-dominated industry. 

The Gist

Since 2011, I've been struggling with chronic pain in the right side of my body, emanating from tears in my shoulder. Without access to health insurance in the States, I've been traveling back and forth to Ecuador (where my family is from) for treatment, and underwent surgery last Fall. Though it was unsuccessful, I still owe over $1,000 for it, and continue to pay out of pocket for medical expenses. Since the pain has expanded toward my right hand, writing for more than 30 minutes a day (as well as basic functions) has become impossible, meaning I can't work for a living. I'm stuck in a situation where I can't pay for my healthcare and can't get better without it. Lame!

But I'm not asking for help with my medical costs. A flight from Ecuador to California runs about $700 (with luck) and though the fine folks at VONA have fronted half of my tuition in financial aid, I still owe them $300. I'm asking for at least $900 to help with these costs - but anything at all would be mad mad mad appreciated!

In exchange, I'm offering my zines, photos and writing services as perks!

Every single contributor will receive the zine Dispatches: Conversations with Writers of Color on Race, Place & Adventure, which is a series of interviews I'm conducting in conjunction with this crowdfunding campaign on baniamor.com. Better title forthcoming! Maybe!

Also please keep in mind all perks will be sent in the mail mid-June.

The Deal

Guess what: being super critical of the tourism industry and writing weird travelogue-type creative non-fiction does not have me rolling in dough. I'm ultra-niche - queer, mestiza, broke, disabled, female; I travel the world alone and give no fucks. I'm pretty shameless about the way I live my life, but recognize when it's time to ask for some help! 

What's important to remember is that voices like mine are squelched every single day, that there aren't many folks doing what I'm doing. Things can and should be different. This is where you come in!

Other Ways You Can Help

Let's be real - I've seen a lot of campaigns like this that I couldn't afford to support due to lack of funds, but there are other ways you can help. Share, like and comment on Facebook, follow me on Twitter and Tumblr, purchase a zine on Etsy, follow, like, comment and reblog my stuff on Wordpress, or shoot me an e-mail at heyitsbani at gmail dot com. Shout out and connect!

story:
Debrena's Story

It's been nearly 15 years since two time national best selling author, Debrena Jackson Gandy's last book tour.  

                                                           

Gandy's first national best seller:  Sacred Pampering Principles.          

                                                         

                Gandy's second national best seller: All The Joy You Can Stand.

Gandy's NEWEST Book

Now she finally has a new book coming out, The Love Lies, with the foreword by Actress Kim Coles. A lot has changed in the publishing industry over these past 15 years.  Namely, these changes affect how books are sold and even how they are read, including sending authors on book tours.  Publishers can now only afford to send celebrities and certain politicians on book tours.  

What Debrena Knows For Sure...

For Debrena, who knows that one of the major keys to both of her first two books becoming national best-sellers is her opportunity to meet, greet, hug, and touch people as she travelled around the country on book tour.  A cornerstone of her brand is "high touch and the personal touch.," She is breaking with the current tradition of the publishing industry (book tours being few and far between), and is committed to going on national book tour for The Love Lies, her new third book.

In the Beginning...

What began as a seminar in her living room with eight of her friends four years ago, grew into her love relationships platform, called The Love Academy.  

Soon the requests started to come from all around the country, and a national movement was underway – one in which she would lead Love Academy 101 and 201 intensives, and Men-tality 101 and 201 seminars (for men only) across the country, and over 1,500 would experience her teachings. The success and popularity of her Love Academy teachings is what inspired her new book, The Love Lies.

What You Can Do Right Now!

She is seeking to raise funds for her national book tour.   However, she needs your help to make her national book tour a reality! She plans to visit nine major market and 15 cities over a six-week period, from mid-September thru late October. The Love Lies National Book Tour is being funded by people like you, supporters, readers, friends and associates.


Our Goal & Your Perks

Our goal is to raise $10,000 for this amazing book tour to nine major cities!  Funds raised will go towards airfare, media coordination, book event coordination, ground transportation, and publicity and promotional costs. She plans to visit her NINE MAJOR MARKETS, starting with the Northwest, PLUS The Bay Area; Atlanta; Greenville, SC; Charlotte, NC, Raleigh, NC; Washington D. C./Maryland; Philadelphia, New York and Chicago.

Check out the perks as our way of saying thank you for contributing to the movement! 

The Impact

In the few years that she’s been sharing her teachings and principles in the format of The Love Academy and Men-tality, the stories have been pouring in….the mindsets that are changing; the relationships that have been salvaged; the healing that is occurring; the emotional baggage from the past that is being released; the new perspectives that are emerging; the new hope for love that is birthed; the marriages that have been revitalized; and the new relationships, engagements and marriages that have occurred as a result of participants applying the principles. This is more than a book – it is the start of a Relationships Revolution.

Here's what others are saying about Debrena and this Relationships Revolution:



Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and we get that BUT that doesn't mean you can't help make a national best seller.  You can share this campaign on all of your social networks, send an email, tell a friend or several friends.  All of our single actions together will help make it happen!

JOIN THE RELATIONSHIPS REVOLUTION!

With love and gratitude,


--TEAM DEBRENA!

story:
What is AINT Magazine?

We all create narratives about ourselves and our lives.  We recount experiences and anecdotes which portray ourselves in a way we want the world to see us.  These narratives aren’t always true, they’re influenced by ourselves as the storytellers and how we want the story, and ourselves, to be perceived.  AINT magazine is an art photography and interview publication that does the same, except I curate the narratives and stories from interviews and conversations whilst photographing each edition's interviewee.

I've been taking photographs for the past decade and my work is in private collections in Europe and Australia.  I now want to share my photography with others in a new way via the format of a photographic magazine.  The idea evolved to encompass not only photographing the people I work with, but to also interview them, to get their stories, their views, to get under their skin a bit.  Their stories inform the photography, which then guides the conversations we have.  This is AINT Magazine.

I consider AINT Magazine an open ended single publication with no destination, guided only by the process.  It is divided into chapters, one of which will be published every two months, each with a different interviewee, each contributing to the whole work.

Please have a look at my other photography at Ede Strong's Blog, this will give you an idea of what inspires me; how I see the world; the images I love taking; everything I'll bring to AINT Magazine.

To begin with, the magazine will be produced on high-quality newsprint, combining art photography and text taken from the interviews.  Over time the format may change: the aim is the project.  Everything is open to development and evolution.  AINT Magazine will never have advertising, which is why I want to keep it completely independent through sales and subscriptions.

What are my goals, what support do I need, and why?

    I'm looking to raise £500 in order to fund the initial print run of AINT Magazine, as well as pay for the creation of a digital platform for the magazine.

    If I don't raise the full amount, I will still proceed with the initial print run for all my supporters, as well as fulfil all the perks offered.  The aim is to get my work into the hands of my supporters, those who appreciate the artistry and intent of my project.  If I fail to achieve my target, the digital platform will come later, funded by sales of the magazine.

    Chapter 1 of AINT Magazine has been photographed, laid out, proofed and ready to print.  All supporters of this campaign will get their copy before it becomes available through any other outlets.  Supporters will also get limited edition photography goodies, like postcards, posters and even photographic prints.


      If you can't help financially...

      • I totally understand if you're not in a position to support AINT Magazine financially.  That's totally ok, but there are other ways you might be able to help.
      • Get in touch.  I love hearing from people.  Even if you just like something on my blog, let me know, it would mean the world to me!  Ultimately I just want to get my photography in front of people who appreciate it.
      • If you know people who would be interested in this project please tell them about it.  You might just introduce them to something they love!
      • Stay in touch!  So you can get up to date information about the magazine, have a look at my Facebook page, where I'll post progress reports, news and other updates.
